none: Postcard to Louis L. McInnis from A. P. Stewart, October 12, 1882
Postcard to Louis L. McInnis from A. P. Stewart, October 12, 1882
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 12 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: A postcard from A. P. Stewart at the University of Mississippi to Professor Louis L. McInnis at the Agricultural & Mechanical College of Texas, dated October 12, 1882, recommending Charles S. Stewart, Jr., a recent graduate from Amite City, Louisiana, for a teaching position. Stewart notes that the candidate is a conscientious scholar but may have constraints due to family circumstances and requests that McInnis contact University of Mississippi faculty members for references.

body.value:
POSTAL CARD.

[Stamp: OXFORD / OCT / 2 / MISS.]

NOTHING BUT THE ADDRESS CAN BE PLACED ON THIS SIDE.

[Margin: 1881
Oct
21
Ans]

Prof. L. L. McInnis
A. & M. College of Texas.
College Station,
Texas.

**Image Analysis and Transcription: A Postcard from Oxford, Mississippi** Alright, let's break this down. First, the obvious: it's a U.S. Postal Card. The header's in that decorative banner, "POSTAL CARD." The postmark says "OXFORD / OCT / 2 / MISS." and there's a cancelled one-cent stamp – "U.S. POSTAGE." – right there. The printed instruction, `NOTHING BUT THE ADDRESS CAN BE PLACED ON THIS SIDE.`, is a good reminder. Now, the address: "Prof. L. L. McInnis" at "A. & M. College of Texas." in "College Station, Texas." That's the main point. Then there's the margin note. It looks like filing information. The date definitely looks like 1881, not 1887 or 1882. I can see the "Oct" clearly, then "21," and what looks like "Ans," short for "Answered." The first digit of the top number really looks like a "2," but given the context of a date, I think it's just a sloppy "1". It's a bit scrawled, but contextually it's the most likely explanation. So, here's my transcription in the proper format: `

POSTAL CARD.

` `

[Stamp: OXFORD / OCT / 2 / MISS.]

` `

NOTHING BUT THE ADDRESS CAN BE PLACED ON THIS SIDE.

` `

[Margin: 1881 / Oct / 21 / Ans]

` `

Prof. L. L. McInnis
` `A. & M. College of Texas.
` `College Station,
` `Texas.

` The "A. & M." is a bit messy, but that's just how the handwriting is. The key thing is that it represents "Agricultural and Mechanical College," and "A. & M." is the standard abbreviation. It would be a useful thing to add in any metadata, as that would enhance the information presented.

[Header]

Univ. of Miss. Oct 12 82

Prof. McInnis
I have just been talk-
ing with Dr. Little & another
member of the Faculty in
reference to your need.
They told me to recommend
to you my nephew, Chas. S.
Stewart, Jr., of Amite City, Lou-
isiana. Graduated June last -
a good scholar - very conscien-
tious & faithful. He was to have
taken a place in a school in
Memphis but was prevented
by the death of his mother
& illness of his father. I do
not know whether he could
accept the position - (pass'd
by records & moral), if there
be a prospect of permanence
& of promotion. I will write
to him - & you can learn all
about him by writing to
some of the members of our
Faculty -

Truly yours,

[Signature]

A. P. Stewart

The handwriting looks like 19th-century cursive, and it seems to be in ink. The header says "Univ. of Miss. Oct 12 82," and the salutation is "Prof. McInnis." The letter writer is A.P. Stewart, and he's recommending his nephew, Charles S. Stewart, Jr., to Professor McInnis for a position, likely a teaching one. The task is to get a perfect transcription of it. Mentally rotating the letter, I can see the lines running vertically now. Let's see... the handwriting is a bit tricky, but I'll focus on each word carefully, starting with the header. After the header, it's the salutation, then the body. I will rotate mentally to read the text. First, I need to transcribe the text. I will write" * **Next:** "to him - & you can learn all" * **Next:** "about him by writing to" * **Next:** "some of the members of our" * **Next:** "Faculty -" * **Next:** "Truly yours," * **Next:** "A. Or even a completely different word? It looks like the word starts with "p...". Okay, now rechecking the crucial phrase: "accept the position - (pass'd by records & moral)...". I keep going over it. The context seems to be about the nephew's qualifications and the conditions of the job offer. I'm thinking that it likely contains a description of the nephew's qualifications.
